Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 04:37PM jordan wrote: I understand your worry. None of us knows our longevity - cancer survivors or not. Your wife is almost a 2 yr survivor.  You are right, with so many good treatments & more coming all the time this is much more a chronic disease.  If the Arimidex stops being effective at some point there are many, many other treatment options -- all very good.  I just celebrated 7 yrs since diagnosis in June 2001.  I've been stage Iv since 9/02 when bone mets were found.  I've been on several different treatments over the years. I'm still stable, still strong, and planning to be around for many many more years.
Posts.Title: Stage IV Encouragement Wanted Baziotes plc

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 09:12AM jordan wrote: Were you ever on taxotere?  I had severe pleural effusions after taking taxotere for several months.  Had to have thoracentisis done 2x on each lung.  They did not find cancer cells in the fluid.  It can be a side effect of taxotere (& maybe other chemos?)  That was 4 yrs ago - they've never completely gone away - show up as minor on scans & don't bother me.  (I'm praying they're still non cancer!)
Posts.Title: Pleural Effusion TonyaB jordan

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2008 04:21AM jordan wrote: Diane -- I agree with others - there's no right or wrong answer here.  Either taxol or xeloda will be a good choice.  I don't have experience with taxol/avastin (yet - I'm sure it's in my future) but wanted to speak to the xeloda.  I've been on xeloda for almost 4 yrs.  It's kept my bone mets stable.  The plus for me:  kept my hair, easy, pill form/no infusions, feel great-no fatigue, nausea.  I had lots of diarrhea in the beginning, but it finally settled down & now not an issue at all - I think my system just had to adjust to it.  The downside for me has been the hand/foot issue, but my dr. adjusted my dosage which has helped & I've learned to keep on top of it with lotions etc.  HOpe this helps.
Posts.Title: Made a decision....I think? :o) badboob67 Kasey

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 04:51PM jordan wrote: Dragonfly - I was dx 7 yrs ago as stage III.  14 months later bone mets were found in a rib.  I still have only bone mets - in a few ribs & a couple of vertebrae.  I started out on different hormonals, but they didn't work well for me, so I've been on various chemo meds.  I'm her2+ so have had herceptin also.  Plus aredia for bone strengthening and repair.  I'm doing well for over 5 yrs now with bone mets.  I just wanted to add this to say there are MANY good treatments and you can keep things stable.  This is a wonderful site for for information and support.  You'll find lots of help here.
Posts.Title: FRom A 11 to Iv in 30 seconds Dragonfly-4 Gitane

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 03:46PM jordan wrote: Deb - I agree with the others that's it's mostly likely the decadron.  and like the others I hate it's effects too.  And have had to have it with earlier chemos. I just started taxol & avastin on Wed.  I get decadron only in the IV.  My doc wanted me to start with 20 mg.  I refused & he cut it in half to 10 mg.  The 10 mg. hasn't been too bad this week, but I'm going to ask him if he'd lower it to 8 mg next week, and if I can handle that, maybe can go even lower on it.  We'll see.
Posts.Title: Right on schedule, emotional overload…. AlaskaDeb jordan

Posts.Content: jordan wrote: I just got home from the hospital tonight.  I was there 4 days with a staff infection around my port site which resulted in it having to be removed.  I wrote about this on a different thread.  I have a 1 inch long 1/2 inch deep hole near my clavicle where the infection was really bad & it's packed & dressed & will take a long tme to heal from the inside.  Before all this happened to my port I'd written on another subject on how my tumor markers ca2729 has been rising for the last months from 200 to 480.  My pet/ct scans are stable but my onc. wants to switch me to different chemo thinking the marker indicates something's brewing.  The surgeon who removed the port this week said it was deeply infected -- luckily hadn't spread to the blood stream!  He didn't say how long he'd thought it was there, but probably festering for sometime before it was noticable / painful.  Okay I'm wondering if the infection has been there for a few months maybe could that have affected the tumor marker numbers?  Would that be possible?  Maybe a non-cancer explanation for the rise in numbers? Dx 6/2001, IBC, Stage IV, Grade 2, ER+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: update on port infection & question on tumor marker jordan LuAnnH

Posts.Content: May 10, 2008 07:53AM jordan wrote: River - I've just reconnected with this site.  I took a LONG break from it for the same reasons.  I've really appreciated your messages and wish you well.
Posts.Title: Coming off for awhile riverinerabbit minette

Posts.Content: May 10, 2008 07:50AM jordan wrote: Oh, Ozzie, I feel you!  I'm about to lose my hair for the 3rd time.  I start taxol & avastin next week.   I'm stressing about it all - including & especially the hair loss.  I hate wigs & scarves too for the same reasons you describe - hot, itchy.  I remember wearing a wig for 'dress up', scarves for 'everyday' and sometimes just going bald.  I don't know what my comfort routine will be this time around.  I am going to shop for a different wig though in hopes that if I can find one I like better it will help.  I also hate the thought of losing eye brows & lashes again  I know it's vanity, but I finally feel like I look 'good' & people say they like my hair style, color in my skin is good, etc.  now all that will change.   Sorry I'm not giving you any help, just doing my own venting. It's one of the main reasons I dont want to do an IV chemo too.  I'm also afraid of what the other s/e will be for me too. I hope you get that port soon.  I just had to get my port replaced a few weeks ago.  I don't think I could handle going through this without one. Sorry, no tips, but I truly understand, Ozzie.
Posts.Title: HAIR LOSS ozzie2 maggie1984

Posts.Content: May 11, 2008 10:46AM jordan wrote: Ozzie, I want to disagree with that onc. who said 'when you do iv chemo you are in late stages'.  I don't think that's true at all - it's just that chemo by iv is the best treatment option for what's needed at the time.
Posts.Title: HAIR LOSS ozzie2 maggie1984

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 07:11AM jordan wrote: I just started taxol & avastin and am about to lose my hair for the 3rd time.  I am mourning over it too.  I went shopping yesterday for a cranial prosthesis - love the insurance lingo for a wig! My question.... how many times can one lose hair & it will come back?  After I lost it the 1st time it grew back okay - really no change in texture, thickness, etc from original.  But after I lost it th 2nd time, when it grew back it was very thin, not at all like the full head of hair I used to have.  It was workable, but visibly looked much thinner.  Now losing this again..... will it even grow back?  or be even thinner yet?
Posts.Title: HAIR LOSS ozzie2 maggie1984

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 04:59PM jordan wrote: Irina -- That IS good news.  A 400 pt drop is huge.  The treatment is working.  I don't think the important part is so much the number itself, but the pattern over time & yours is a significant decrease.  Congratulations!  How do you feel on the taxol/avastin?  It's likely in my future.
Posts.Title: Good news Irina lemonld

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 08:08AM jordan wrote: I was on xeloda & herceptin for 3 yrs, then a yr ago switched to xeloda & tykerb.  It has worked very well for me.  I am her2 +.  As others have said this is a very effective combo for her2+.  I've not heard of the other drug.  Will they do a biopsy of the breast mass to see if it's a progression of the same cancer or maybe a different type?
Posts.Title: Vinorelbine or Xeloda? mason204 mason204

Posts.Content: May 18, 2008 08:01PM jordan wrote: Sounds like we are on the same treatment & schedule.  I had my 1st treatment of taxol/avastin last Wed.  Not too bad... Fri/Sat had bone pain & was achy.  i've had some stomach cramps - almost like menstrual cramps (or what I remember they were like) but no nausea.   I really have a hard time with the sleeplessness that the decadron causes. I'll have my next treatment - taxol only - this Wed.  I have 3 wks of taxol, then the 4th week off, with avastin every 1 & 3 week.  For me it will be indefinitely - as long as it it works - hopefully will get me to NED! I wonder if we'll feel more effects once we've had more treatments & they start to accumulate. My hair hasn't started to come out yet, but I suppose that will be soon.  I'm dreading that - it will be my 3rd time to lose my hair.
Posts.Title: Not too bad! lusianagal sue3645

Posts.Content: May 1, 2008 05:06AM jordan wrote: LuAnn -- You are in my thoughts too. It's so unfair to have to face so many procedures and complications.  I hope this goes really smoothly for you will little discomfort.  I just had my day surgery yesterday.  New port inserted and the wound from my old port debrided.  I was dreading having to go for this and now am relieved to have it done & overwith.  You'll be feeling that same relief too once you're home again today.  Wishing you well.
Posts.Title: Send some good thoughts, outpatient surgery tomorrow LuAnnH djd

Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 10:44AM jordan wrote: Calgal -- I'm trying to do my water fitness 2-3 times a week & keep activity up, but it's hard when the fatigue hits.  I agree it's a real struggle & the weight gain is such an insult on top of all the rest.  I put this on your other thread, but decided to copy it here too:  I'm on taxol & avastin.  I know taxol & abraxane are in the same family.  But i'm confused on how similar they are.  I've heard they are 'packaged' differently so that the abraxane doesn't require the pre-meds, but the taxol does.  Other than that are there more differences in the drug or are they the same thing?  If they are the same, then are the s/e the same?  And why would it be beneficial to change from one to the other when one stops working?  I'm curious.  Thanks.
Posts.Title: weight gain on taxol & avastin? jordan debstitchestoo

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 06:17AM jordan wrote: I started xeloda at 3500mg day.  Then cut the dose to 3000mg to lessen h/f syndrome.  That was still hard on the hand/foot so eventually I did 3000mg a day for 11 days instead of the 14 followed by 10 days off (so same 21 day cycle).  That worked really well, gave my hands/feet more time to recover and still was effective against progression for 3 1/2 yrs.
Posts.Title: XELODIANS, what is your dose? badboob67 Bronx81

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 05:11PM jordan wrote: I do have bone mets.  I've been dealing with them for about 5 yrs now.  I do have pain in my left hip - I sleep on the left side a lot & it hurts often when lying down & also sometimes when walking - not constantly, but on & off.  I do NOT have mets in that hip area.  Not sure what it is.... maybe arthritis?  As long as it's not cancer I don't really care! My bone mets are only in a couple of vertebrae & ribs. And I have very little discomfort in the area where there are mets.  So I just want to assure you that what you are experiencing may not be mets in the hip or spine at all, but some other cause.  Of course, you'll sleep easier by getting it checked out.  Best of luck.
Posts.Title: bone mets?? MaryK9 LuAnnH

Posts.Content: jordan wrote: I just started taxol & avastin. I had my 3rd weekly treatment yesterday. Already I've gained 5 pounds and I don't think I've done anything else differently. Do people gain weight on this combo? For pre-meds I'm getting aloxi, zantac, & benadryl. The 1st wk I got 10 mg of decadron, 2nd wk 5 mg, and now I can get by without decadron. I know decadron can cause weight gain too. I've asked not to get it for other reasons, I really have trouble with it's side effects. So far other than slight side effects of achiness, dry throat, my biggest issue has been constipation with this chemo. I was on xeloda/tykerb for over 3 yrs before having to switch to taxol/avastin. On that I was able to lose weight & keep it off. I still need to lose 15-20 more pounds and am now concerned that I'll be gaining weight back. Maybe weight gain isnt the biggest issue in the big picture of this disease, but I'm trying to get to a normal weight for me & not be so overweight. The data on being overweight & increased risk with breast cancer is compelling me. I know others here are on taxol / avastin.   Has weight gain been a common issue? Thanks. Dx 6/2001, IBC, Stage IV, Grade 2, ER+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: weight gain on taxol & avastin? jordan debstitchestoo

Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 09:56PM jordan wrote: Deb -  I do get aredia once a month too.  It seems your s/e on the taxol & avastin are pretty tough.  Do you have it the same schedule as I'm going to have?  Taxol every week for 3 weeks & avastin every other week?  (the 4th week off).  I'm really nervous about how I'll feel.  I still work full time & need to be able to continue to work.  My work - I work for a church - is VERY supportive and accommodating, but there is a limit.  Luann - No I have not had a spinal fluid or bone marrow test.  It hasn't been suggested.... why do you suggest that?  If cancer was found there would the treatment - chemo be the same or would that call for something different? I'm also worried that with taxol & avastin there 's nothing that's addressing the her2+.  And I felt 'safer' with xeloda & tykerb knowing there was some protection for brain mets as they cross the bb barrier.  I'm not in a good state right now.  I've this written on another thread but .... a  month ago I got an infection at my port site, had to have it removed, meds for infection, still healing from that.  Last week I had a new port put in -- & now healing from that too.  I'm very fatigued from just going through all of that & now starting a chemo when I'm already feeling depleted.  Thank God I have a port since I'll be using it weekly now. Thank you for your encouragement & good thoughts.
Posts.Title: so discouraged I need some help jordan jordan

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 03:22PM jordan wrote: Wow, I just finished talking with the scheduler & got my appointments lined up for the next 5 weeks.  I felt so depressed & started to cry afterwards.  then I opened this page & found more encouragement & support.  You are the best.  I know I'm not the only one - obviously - dealing with having to start a new tx, hair loss, new side effects & everything involved - right now I feel huge anxiety & dread.  Part of it is the huge blow that I need to actually start this again, part is fear of the unknown, fear of the side effects, & yes, fear of this stupid disease.  I'm encouraged to hear from you, Lynn, that you worked on this tx, and from others too that you feel it's tolerable.  Luisagal - I wish my dr. would start me on a low dose too, but his pattern has been to start on high dose & adjust down if need be.  I was first on aredia, then was switched to zometa, but my dr. switched me back to aredia because of the data on bone issues.  I did get lots of neuropathy & bone/joint pain when I was on taxol yrs ago, so I suppose I'll have that again.  It was bad.  No one has mentioned nails falling off, bad taste in mouth.  I had that really bad with taxotere, but don't think it's part of the taxol s/e.  I'm worried about the nosebleeds some of you say you have on avastin - how severe or frequent are these?
Posts.Title: so discouraged I need some help jordan jordan

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2008 05:56PM jordan wrote: Thanks, LuAnn. I'll check out that website.  You are so helpful.  I just got a call from my onc.  telling me that he wants me to have a ct scan to see if they can get a measurable amount on my bone mets to see if I can qualify for that trial.  He said there's a chance & worth a try.  I sure hope it works because I think it would be my best option right now. The trial is herceptin plus a new chemo under trial & it is a targeted therapy.
Posts.Title: ixempra - any one have any experience with it?: jordan luvyoumom

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2008 09:47PM jordan wrote: Thanks for your feedback Kasey on the ixempra.  I hope that & the xeloda work well.  I've not had any bad side effects from the xeloda so hope you dont either. mthompson ---- hope you get good news on the scans tomorrow.  I I wonder if the trial goes to phase III if they'll also be more broad on the qualifications to get in.  Is anyone on this site on that trial?
Posts.Title: ixempra - any one have any experience with it?: jordan luvyoumom

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2008 07:29AM jordan wrote: Jim - I was on xeloda/tykerb for a long time, then my  tumor markers started to rise like you wife's.  The scans didn't show anything new, but my onc. thought a different treatment was appropriate because of the tumor marker pattern.  I am not on taxol & avastin.  I've been on it for about 6 wks & the tumor marker is coming down.  I'm not on either tykerb or herceptin right now which makes me a little nervous, but it the taxol/avastin is effect & guess that's what counts.  T or H will be back in my future I'm sure.  The really promising trial is will trasmuzab (herceptin) plus MCC-DM1.  There's a phase II trial which i heard just closed, but another one approved & opening soon.  Go to cancer.gov & clinical trials & search for it for more info. I'm hoping i can get into it when it opens.   It is sponsored by Genentech.  LuAnn -- great consice list of meds.  I'm going to copy that for future reference. Thanks. Jordan
Posts.Title: after xyloda/tykerb????? jim2 jordan

Posts.Content: jordan wrote: Just saw the oncologist today.  After a few months of wavering about having to switch chemos he says I can't delay any longer.  I've been on xeloda for 3 1/2 yrs, first with herceptin, then for the last yr with tykerb.  The combos have worked well for me & kept my mets stable.  Easy to take a few pills everyday, h/f syndrome the worst of the s/e, but tolerable.  My latest PET & CT scans show stable mets in the bones -- nothing really changed.  BUT my ca2729 has risen steadily for last 6 months.  Today 600 -- up from 460 3 weeks ago.  I should feel great that I got almost 4 yrs feeling good on an easy chemo for me, but I'm only feeling depressed that I can't continue on it and will have to change - that this damn cancer is still here - real - & threatening.  I think I have been in a little denial zone for awhile -- resisting the reality that this day would come. Next week I start taxol & avastin.  Taxol 3 wks on, 1 wk off.  Avastin every other week. I had 4 cycles of taxol years ago (3weeks apart) & thought it was terrible -- lots of bone pain, neuropathy.  I don't know if the weekly will be easier.  I dread having to be in the dr. office on IV every week again.  I really dread having to lose my hair (for the 3rd time).  I dread having to tell my 2 sons (31 & 28) who both are so scared they freak out & I can't handle that on top of everything else.  I dread not knowing how I'll do on this chemo.... will it work? how will I feel? What's going on inside my body that the scans don't show?  I also have pleural effusions -- they developed from a side effect of taxotere about 5 yrs ago.  They were really bad & I had them drained.  They tested the fluid then & no sign of cancer - said it was likely the taxotere effect on me.  They've never completely gone away, altough have been small.  Now I'm worried that's why the tumor marker is rising that there's cancer there maybe.  I forgot to ask the dr. today what he thought about that.  I know there are people on this site who are on taxol avastin so I will look for your posts.  But any help you can add here on that chemo, effusions, etc.  I thank you for listening. Dx 6/2001, IBC, Stage IV, Grade 2, ER+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: so discouraged I need some help jordan jordan

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 04:19PM jordan wrote: Deb -- You put the right perspective on it.... successful treatment, reduction in cancer, no progression, hopefully ned - keep the goal in mind.  I'm so glad to hear your results are so good & in a short time too.  I have to work full time - too young to retire, can't afford not to work as long as I can.  Luckily I work for a church & this is the best place i could be right now.  The other staff and the congregation are so supportive, helpful, and give me leeway as far as time off etc.  This is one big blessing I have. At home.... I'm divorced so all the financial & living stuff is on me.  Right now my son, his fiance & their 10 month old baby (my grandson!) are living with me.  You'd think that would be a help, but it sort of makes more work & definitely more hectic.  I don't know how long term it will be.  If they'd do more projects for me it would be great, but the reality is that's not happening.  It is a wonderful day brightener to have this little sweet baby to love & laugh with~
Posts.Title: so discouraged I need some help jordan jordan

Posts.Content: jordan wrote: Ixempra is one of the possible chemos that my dr. is suggesting to me.  I'm currently on xeloda & tykerb.  I've read that ixempra can be used alone or with xeloda.  Is anyone here on it?  How are side effects, etc?  Thanks. Dx 6/2001, IBC, Stage IV, Grade 2, ER+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: ixempra - any one have any experience with it?: jordan luvyoumom

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2008 08:33AM jordan wrote: That herceptin + mccdm1 (or something like that) IS the trial I'm trying to get into.  It's only a phase II, but appeals to me because it uses herceptin in a new way with a targeted chemo.  I'm having a ct scan to see if I can qualify, but as of now only have bone mets which the trial doesn't accept.  The ct scan will have to identify a measurable spot of at least 1 cm in soft tissue/lymph node for me to qualify.  I WANT to be in the study, but I DON't want new cancer to be found outside of the bones.  Hard to know what to pray for sometimes!
Posts.Title: ixempra - any one have any experience with it?: jordan luvyoumom
